sn19.14:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ itthiṃ duggandhaṃ maṅguliṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantiṃ.
sn19.14:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a woman stinking and dingy as a catfish flying through the air.
sn19.14:1.1.comm: Maṅguli is probably related to maṅgura (cf. Sanskrit maṅgura, madgura), a skin color, neither black nor brown, said by the commentary to be that of the common catfish clarias magur (MN 36:29.3). It has a dingy mud-green color for hiding in the mud on the riverbed. It is a pun: she is a seer of maṅgalā (“auspicies”), hence she is reborn ugly as a maṅguli (“catfish”). Like the catfish, she has to disguise her true nature. The idea approaches the modern sense of “catfishing”, both usages stemming from the idea of camouflage.

sn19.14:1.2.pli: Tamenaṃ gijjhāpi kākāpi kulalāpi anupatitvā anupatitvā vitacchenti virājenti.
sn19.14:1.2.eng: Vultures, crows, and hawks kept chasing her, pecking and clawing

sn19.14:1.4.pli: esā, bhikkhave, itthī imasmiṃyeva rājagahe ikkhaṇikā ahosi …pe….
sn19.14:1.4.eng: “That woman used to be a sorceress right here in Rājagaha. …”
sn19.14:1.4.comm: Ikkhaṇikā (Sanskrit īkṣaṇikā) is literally a “seeress”, but her putative powers extend beyond mere visions of the future. Such sorceresses were considered a “thorn” to society alongside dissemblers, cheats, gamblers, and palmists (Manu 9.258). Medhātithi comments that they would con wealthy men out of money by promising them the favors of the gods or casting spells. Jain texts say a sorceress would jingle a small bell under her ear, at the sound of which her familiar, a malevolent entity, would approach and whisper secrets. The Pali commentary concurs: “It seems they do the work of an enslaved spirit, saying, ‘When such and such an offering ritual is performed, you will certainly prosper’.” Perhaps it was this spirit who caused her foul smell (Atharva Veda 8.6.12, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.2.2). The background story to Ja 126 tells how such a sorceress was enlisted by a prince to ensure he would end up with his princess, who was also his cousin. Her powers—all fake—included divination of possession, exorcism, and revivifying a corpse with a malevolent spirit. Kauṭilya, ever the pragmatist, is not above enlisting sorceresses in the services of the state for the dissemination of fake news (Arthaśāstra 13.1.7).

sn19.15:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ itthiṃ uppakkaṃ okiliniṃ okiriniṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantiṃ.
sn19.15:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a scorched woman, sooty and sweaty, flying through the air,

sn19.15:1.3.pli: esā, bhikkhave, itthī kaliṅgassa rañño aggamahesī ahosi.
sn19.15:1.3.eng: “That woman used to be the king of Kaliṅga’s chief queen.

sn19.15:1.4.eng: She was of jealous nature, and poured a brazier of hot coals over her co-wife. …” …

sn19.16:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ asīsakaṃ kabandhaṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantaṃ.
sn19.16:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a headless trunk flying through the air.

sn19.16:1.2.pli: Tassa ure akkhīni ceva honti mukhañca.
sn19.16:1.2.eng: Its eyes and mouth were on its chest.

sn19.16:1.3.pli: Tamenaṃ gijjhāpi kākāpi kulalāpi anupatitvā anupatitvā vitacchenti virājenti.
sn19.16:1.3.eng: Vultures, crows, and hawks kept chasing it, pecking and clawing

sn19.16:1.5.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe hāriko nāma coraghātako ahosi …pe….
sn19.16:1.5.eng: “That being used to be an executioner named Taker right here in Rājagaha. …”
sn19.16:1.5.comm: He would, obviously, decapitate his victims. For his name hārika, compare the suicide weapon (satthahāraka) which according to the commentary is a “taker of life” MN 145:5.32.

sn19.17:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ bhikkhuṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantaṃ.
sn19.17:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a monk flying through the air.

sn19.17:1.2.pli: Tassa saṅghāṭipi ādittā sampajjalitā sajotibhūtā, pattopi āditto sampajjalito sajotibhūto, kāyabandhanampi ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ, kāyopi āditto sampajjalito sajotibhūto.
sn19.17:1.2.eng: His outer robe, bowl, belt, and body were burning, blazing, and glowing

sn19.17:1.4.pli: eso, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kassapassa sammāsambuddhassa pāvacane pāpabhikkhu ahosi …pe….
sn19.17:1.4.eng: “That monk used to be a bad monk in the time of Buddha Kassapa’s dispensation. …”
sn19.17:1.4.comm: The bad monastics are tormented by the requisites that are the signs of their monastic commitment, offered to them out of faith by the lay community.

sn19.18:1.1.eng: “I saw a nun flying through the air.

sn19.18:1.3.eng: “She used to be a bad nun …”

sn19.19:1.1.eng: “I saw a trainee nun flying through the air.

sn19.19:1.3.eng: “She used to be a bad trainee nun …”

sn19.2:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ maṃsapesiṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantiṃ.
sn19.2:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a scrap of meat flying through the air.

sn19.2:1.2.pli: Tamenaṃ gijjhāpi kākāpi kulalāpi anupatitvā anupatitvā vitacchenti virājenti.
sn19.2:1.2.eng: Vultures, crows, and hawks kept chasing it, pecking and clawing

sn19.2:1.4.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe goghātako ahosi …pe….
sn19.2:1.4.eng: “That being used to be a cattle butcher right here in Rājagaha. …”

sn19.20:1.1.eng: “I saw a novice monk flying through the air.

sn19.20:1.2.comm: This seems to be editorial sloppiness, as novices don’t have a saṅghāṭi.

sn19.20:1.3.eng: “He used to be a bad novice monk …”

sn19.21:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ sāmaṇeriṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantiṃ.
sn19.21:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a novice nun flying through the air.

sn19.21:1.2.pli: Tassā saṅghāṭipi ādittā sampajjalitā sajotibhūtā, pattopi āditto sampajjalito sajotibhūto, kāyabandhanampi ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ, kāyopi āditto sampajjalito sajotibhūto.
sn19.21:1.2.eng: Her outer robe, bowl, belt, and body were burning, blazing, and glowing

sn19.21:1.6.eng: That there can be such a sentient being,

sn19.21:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

sn19.21:2.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are disciples who live full of vision and knowledge,

sn19.21:2.3.pli: ñāṇabhūtā vata, bhikkhave, sāvakā viharanti, yatra hi nāma sāvako evarūpaṃ ñassati vā dakkhati vā sakkhiṃ vā karissati.
sn19.21:2.3.eng: since a disciple knows, sees, and witnesses such a thing.

sn19.21:2.4.pli: Pubbeva me sā, bhikkhave, sāmaṇerī diṭṭhā ahosi.
sn19.21:2.4.eng: Formerly, I too saw that novice nun, but I did not speak of it.

sn19.21:2.6.pli: Ahañcetaṃ byākareyyaṃ, pare ca me na saddaheyyuṃ.
sn19.21:2.6.eng: For if I had spoken of it others would not have believed me,

sn19.21:2.7.pli: Ye me na saddaheyyuṃ, tesaṃ taṃ assa dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
sn19.21:2.7.eng: which would be for their lasting harm and suffering.

sn19.21:2.8.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, sāmaṇerī kassapassa sammāsambuddhassa pāvacane pāpasāmaṇerī ahosi.
sn19.21:2.8.eng: That female novice used to be a bad novice nun in the time of the Buddha Kassapa’s dispensation.

sn19.21:2.9.pli: Sā tassa kammassa vipākena bahūni vassāni bahūni vassasatāni bahūni vassasahassāni bahūni vassasatasahassāni niraye paccitvā tasseva kammassa vipākāvasesena evarūpaṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ paṭisaṃvedayatī”ti.
sn19.21:2.9.eng: As a result of that deed she burned in hell for many years, many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of years. Now she experiences the residual result of that deed in such an incarnation.”

sn19.21:4.5.eng: The Linked Discourses with Mark are complete.

sn19.3:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ maṃsapiṇḍaṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantaṃ.
sn19.3:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a piece of flesh flying through the air.

sn19.3:1.2.pli: Tamenaṃ gijjhāpi kākāpi kulalāpi anupatitvā anupatitvā vitacchenti virājenti.
sn19.3:1.2.eng: Vultures, crows, and hawks kept chasing it, pecking and clawing

sn19.3:1.4.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe sākuṇiko ahosi …pe….
sn19.3:1.4.eng: “That being used to be a bird hunter right here in Rājagaha. …”

sn19.4:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ nicchaviṃ purisaṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantaṃ.
sn19.4:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a flayed man flying through the air.

sn19.4:1.2.pli: Tamenaṃ gijjhāpi kākāpi kulalāpi anupatitvā anupatitvā vitacchenti virājenti.
sn19.4:1.2.eng: Vultures, crows, and hawks kept chasing it, pecking and clawing

sn19.4:1.4.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe orabbhiko ahosi …pe….
sn19.4:1.4.eng: “That being used to be a sheep butcher right here in Rājagaha. …”

sn19.5:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ asilomaṃ purisaṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantaṃ.
sn19.5:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a man whose body hairs were swords flying through the air.

sn19.5:1.2.pli: Tassa te asī uppatitvā uppatitvā tasseva kāye nipatanti.
sn19.5:1.2.eng: And those swords kept rising up and falling on his body

sn19.5:1.4.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe sūkariko ahosi …pe….
sn19.5:1.4.eng: “That being used to be a pig butcher right here in Rājagaha. …”
sn19.5:1.4.comm: He is stabbed like he used to stab his pigs.

sn19.6:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ sattilomaṃ purisaṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantaṃ.
sn19.6:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a man whose body hairs were spears flying through the air.

sn19.6:1.2.pli: Tassa tā sattiyo uppatitvā uppatitvā tasseva kāye nipatanti.
sn19.6:1.2.eng: And those spears kept rising up and falling on his body

sn19.6:1.4.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe māgaviko ahosi …pe….
sn19.6:1.4.eng: “That being used to be a deer hunter right here in Rājagaha. …”
sn19.6:1.4.comm: Struck by spears like those he used to bring down his deer quarry.

sn19.7:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ usulomaṃ purisaṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantaṃ.
sn19.7:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a man whose body hairs were arrows flying through the air.

sn19.7:1.2.pli: Tassa te usū uppatitvā uppatitvā tasseva kāye nipatanti.
sn19.7:1.2.eng: And those arrows kept rising up and falling on his body

sn19.7:1.4.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe kāraṇiko ahosi …pe….
sn19.7:1.4.eng: “That being used to be a punisher right here in Rājagaha. …”
sn19.7:1.4.comm: His job is detailed at MN 13:14.3.

sn19.8:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ sūcilomaṃ purisaṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantaṃ.
sn19.8:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a man whose body hairs were needles flying through the air.

sn19.8:1.2.pli: Tassa tā sūciyo uppatitvā uppatitvā tasseva kāye nipatanti.
sn19.8:1.2.eng: And those needles kept rising up and falling on his body

sn19.8:1.4.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe sūto ahosi …pe….
sn19.8:1.4.eng: “That being used to be a marshal right here in Rājagaha. …”
sn19.8:1.4.comm: The sūta were members of the king’s guard (Atharva Veda 3.5.7, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.4.1.7, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.37) standing in seniority between the king’s brother and a village headman (ŚB 5.4.4.17). Later texts say they led the cavalry. They bore quivers of arrows (ŚB 13.4.2.4), which fits their punishment.

sn19.9:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, āvuso, gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohanto addasaṃ sūcilomaṃ purisaṃ vehāsaṃ gacchantaṃ.
sn19.9:1.1.eng: “Just now, reverend, as I was descending from Vulture’s Peak Mountain I saw a man whose body hairs were needles flying through the air.

sn19.9:1.2.pli: Tassa tā sūciyo sīse pavisitvā mukhato nikkhamanti;
sn19.9:1.2.eng: The needles bored into his head and out his mouth,

sn19.9:1.3.eng: into his mouth and out his chest,

sn19.9:1.4.eng: into his chest and out his belly,

sn19.9:1.5.eng: into his belly and out his thighs,

sn19.9:1.6.eng: into his thighs and out his calves,

sn19.9:1.7.eng: and into his calves and out his feet.

sn19.9:1.9.pli: eso, bhikkhave, satto imasmiṃyeva rājagahe sūcako ahosi …pe….
sn19.9:1.9.eng: “That being used to be an informant right here in Rājagaha. …”
sn19.9:1.9.comm: Sūcaka appears only here in Pali. His title echoes his punishment by needles (sūci) which worm their way in and out of his body just as he, as an “informant” (Arthaśāstra 2.8.29) wormed his way through society. Manu says his punishment was to be reborn with a stinking nose (Manu 11.50). As noted in the next Sutta, the informant reported to the “village head”.

sn20.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn20.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn20.1:1.4.pli: “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kūṭāgārassa yā kāci gopānasiyo sabbā tā kūṭaṅgamā kūṭasamosaraṇā kūṭasamugghātā sabbā tā samugghātaṃ gacchanti;
sn20.1:1.4.eng: “Mendicants, the rafters of a bungalow all lean to the peak and meet at the peak, and when the peak is demolished they’re all demolished too.
sn20.1:1.4.comm: While there are several similes elsewhere invoking a roof peak with its rafters, none apply it quite like this.

sn20.1:1.5.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci akusalā dhammā sabbe te avijjāmūlakā avijjāsamosaraṇā avijjāsamugghātā, sabbe te samugghātaṃ gacchanti.
sn20.1:1.5.eng: In the same way all unskillful qualities are rooted in ignorance and meet in ignorance, and when ignorance is demolished they’re all demolished too.

sn20.1:1.6.eng: So you should train like this:

sn20.10:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu ativelaṃ kulesu cārittaṃ āpajjati.
sn20.10:1.2.eng: Now at that time a certain mendicant socialized with families too often.

sn20.10:1.4.eng: “Venerable, don’t socialize with families too often.”

sn20.10:1.5.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi vuccamāno na viramati.
sn20.10:1.5.eng: But that mendicant, when spoken to by the mendicants, did not stop.

sn20.10:1.6.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn20.10:1.6.eng: And then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said:

sn20.10:1.7.pli: “idha, bhante, aññataro bhikkhu ativelaṃ kulesu cārittaṃ āpajjati.

sn20.10:1.10.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi vuccamāno na viramatī”ti.

sn20.10:2.1.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, biḷāro sandhisamalasaṅkaṭīre ṭhito ahosi mudumūsiṃ maggayamāno:
sn20.10:2.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a cat was standing by an alley or a drain or a dustbin hunting a little mouse, thinking,

sn20.10:2.2.pli: ‘yadāyaṃ mudumūsi gocarāya pakkamissati, tattheva naṃ gahetvā khādissāmī’ti.
sn20.10:2.2.eng: ‘When that little mouse comes out to feed, I’ll catch it right there and eat it!’

sn20.10:2.3.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, mudumūsi gocarāya pakkāmi.
sn20.10:2.3.eng: And then that little mouse came out to feed.

sn20.10:2.4.pli: Tamenaṃ biḷāro gahetvā sahasā saṅkhāditvā ajjhohari.
sn20.10:2.4.eng: The cat caught it and hastily swallowed it without chewing.

sn20.10:2.5.pli: Tassa so mudumūsi antampi khādi, antaguṇampi khādi.
sn20.10:2.5.eng: But that little mouse ate its intestines and mesentery,

sn20.10:2.6.pli: So tatonidānaṃ maraṇampi nigacchi maraṇamattampi dukkhaṃ.
sn20.10:2.6.eng: resulting in death and deadly pain.

sn20.10:3.1.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisati arakkhiteneva kāyena arakkhitāya vācāya arakkhitena cittena, anupaṭṭhitāya satiyā, asaṃvutehi indriyehi.
sn20.10:3.1.eng: In the same way, take a certain monk who robes up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, enters the village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.

sn20.10:3.2.pli: So tattha passati mātugāmaṃ dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā.
sn20.10:3.2.eng: There he sees a lady scantily clad, with revealing clothes.

sn20.10:3.3.pli: Tassa mātugāmaṃ disvā dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti.

sn20.10:3.4.pli: So rāgānuddhaṃsena cittena maraṇaṃ vā nigacchati maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
sn20.10:3.4.eng: resulting in death or deadly pain.

sn20.10:3.5.pli: Maraṇañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyassa vinaye yo sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
sn20.10:3.5.eng: For it is death in the training of the Noble One to disavow the training and return to a lesser life.

sn20.10:3.6.pli: Maraṇamattañhetaṃ, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ yadidaṃ aññataraṃ saṅkiliṭṭhaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati.
sn20.10:3.6.eng: And it is deadly pain to commit one of the corrupt offenses
sn20.10:3.6.comm: This is in reference to saṅghādisesa offenses such as masturbation, flirting, or sensual touching.

sn20.10:3.8.eng: So you should train like this:

sn20.10:3.9.pli: ‘rakkhiteneva kāyena rakkhitāya vācāya rakkhitena cittena, upaṭṭhitāya satiyā, saṃvutehi indriyehi gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisissāmā’ti.
sn20.10:3.9.eng: ‘We will enter the village or town for alms guarding body, speech, and mind, establishing mindfulness, and restraining the sense faculties.’

sn20.11:1.2.pli: “Assuttha no tumhe, bhikkhave, rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ jarasiṅgālassa vassamānassā”ti?
sn20.11:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, did you hear an old jackal howling at the crack of dawn?”
sn20.11:1.2.comm: Similar to SN 17.8, but somehow even more brutal in its application.

sn20.11:1.4.pli: “Eso kho, bhikkhave, jarasiṅgālo ukkaṇḍakena nāma rogajātena phuṭṭho.
sn20.11:1.4.eng: “That old jackal has the disease called mange.

sn20.11:1.5.pli: So yena yena icchati tena tena gacchati;
sn20.11:1.5.eng: Yet it still goes where it wants,

sn20.11:1.6.pli: yattha yattha icchati tattha tattha tiṭṭhati;

sn20.11:1.7.pli: yattha yattha icchati tattha tattha nisīdati;

sn20.11:1.8.pli: yattha yattha icchati tattha tattha nipajjati;
sn20.11:1.8.eng: and lies down where it wants.

sn20.11:1.9.eng: And the cool breeze still blows on it.

sn20.11:1.10.pli: Sādhu khvassa, bhikkhave, yaṃ idhekacco sakyaputtiyapaṭiñño evarūpampi attabhāvapaṭilābhaṃ paṭisaṃvediyetha.
sn20.11:1.10.eng: A certain person here who claims to follow the Sakyan would be lucky to experience even such an incarnation.

sn20.11:1.11.eng: So you should train like this:

sn20.12:1.2.pli: “Assuttha no tumhe, bhikkhave, rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ jarasiṅgālassa vassamānassā”ti?
sn20.12:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, did you hear an old jackal howling at the crack of dawn?”

sn20.12:1.4.pli: “Siyā kho, bhikkhave, tasmiṃ jarasiṅgāle yā kāci kataññutā kataveditā, na tveva idhekacce sakyaputtiyapaṭiññe siyā yā kāci kataññutā kataveditā.
sn20.12:1.4.eng: “There might be some gratitude and thankfulness in that old jackal, but there is none in a certain person here who claims to follow the Sakyan.

sn20.12:1.5.eng: So you should train like this:

sn20.12:1.7.pli: na ca no amhesu appakampi kataṃ nassissatī’ti.
sn20.12:1.7.eng: We won’t forget even a small thing done for us.’

sn20.12:2.5.eng: The Linked Discourses with similes are complete.

sn20.2:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā parittaṃ nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsuṃ āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn20.2:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha, picking up a little bit of dirt on his fingernail, addressed the mendicants:

sn20.2:1.4.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yo cāyaṃ mayā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito yā cāyaṃ mahāpathavī”ti?
sn20.2:1.4.eng: Which is more: the little bit of dirt on my fingernail, or this great earth?”

sn20.2:1.5.eng: “Sir, the great earth is far more.

sn20.2:1.6.pli: Appamattakoyaṃ bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito.
sn20.2:1.6.eng: The little bit of dirt on your fingernail is tiny.

sn20.2:1.7.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti upanidhimpi na upeti kalabhāgampi na upeti mahāpathaviṃ upanidhāya bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito”ti.
sn20.2:1.7.eng: Compared to the great earth, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”

sn20.2:1.8.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye manussesu paccājāyanti;
sn20.2:1.8.eng: “In the same way the sentient beings reborn as humans are few,

sn20.2:1.9.pli: atha kho eteyeva bahutarā sattā ye aññatra manussehi paccājāyanti.
sn20.2:1.9.eng: while those not reborn as humans are many.

sn20.2:1.10.eng: So you should train like this:

sn20.3:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yāni kānici kulāni bahutthikāni appapurisāni tāni suppadhaṃsiyāni honti corehi kumbhatthenakehi;
sn20.3:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, those families with many women and few men are easy prey for bandits and  grain-jar thieves.
sn20.3:1.2.comm: AN 8.51:27.1, Kd 20:1.6.7. | Few men and many women is said to be a sign of the end of the world (Harivaṁśa 116.23, Brahma Purāṇa 231.24, Liṅga Purāṇa 1.40.19, Narasiṁha Purāṇa 54.22 ). | The kumbha (“jar”) was a measure of grain by which the severity of theft was measured (Manu 8.320). Perhaps the implication is that these are house-thieves plundering domestic goods, rather than highway robbers.

sn20.3:1.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhuno mettācetovimutti abhāvitā abahulīkatā so suppadhaṃsiyo hoti amanussehi.
sn20.3:1.3.eng: In the same way any mendicant who has not developed and cultivated the heart’s release by love is easy prey for non-humans.

sn20.3:1.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yāni kānici kulāni appitthikāni bahupurisāni tāni duppadhaṃsiyāni honti corehi kumbhatthenakehi;
sn20.3:1.4.eng: Those families with few women and many men are hard prey for bandits and grain-jar thieves.

sn20.3:1.5.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhuno mettācetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā so duppadhaṃsiyo hoti amanussehi.
sn20.3:1.5.eng: In the same way a mendicant who has developed and cultivated the heart’s release by love is hard prey for non-humans.

sn20.3:1.6.eng: So you should train like this:

sn20.3:1.7.pli: ‘mettā no cetovimutti bhāvitā bhavissati bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā’ti.
sn20.3:1.7.eng: ‘We will develop the heart’s release by love. We’ll cultivate it, make it our vehicle and our basis, keep it up, consolidate it, and properly implement it.’

sn20.4:1.2.pli: “Yo, bhikkhave, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ okkhāsataṃ dānaṃ dadeyya, yo majjhanhikasamayaṃ okkhāsataṃ dānaṃ dadeyya, yo sāyanhasamayaṃ okkhāsataṃ dānaṃ dadeyya, yo vā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ antamaso gadduhanamattampi mettacittaṃ bhāveyya, yo vā majjhanhikasamayaṃ antamaso gadduhanamattampi mettacittaṃ bhāveyya, yo vā sāyanhasamayaṃ antamaso gadduhanamattampi mettacittaṃ bhāveyya, idaṃ tato mahapphalataraṃ.
sn20.4:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, suppose one person was to give a gift of a hundred cauldrons of rice in the morning, at midday, and in the evening. And someone else was to develop a heart of love, even just as long as it takes to pull a cow’s udder. The latter would be more fruitful.

sn20.4:1.3.eng: So you should train like this:

sn20.4:1.4.pli: ‘mettā no cetovimutti bhāvitā bhavissati bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā’ti.
sn20.4:1.4.eng: ‘We will develop the heart’s release by love. We’ll cultivate it, make it our vehicle and our basis, keep it up, consolidate it, and properly implement it.’
